docs.abstract: Bangladesh will get $45 million in interest-free loans to help its textile and fertilizer industries, the World Ban k announced today. The loans, to run for 50 years, will be given by t he International Development Association, an affiliate of the bank.  A loan of $30 million will go to rehabilitate 15 plants and install c enters to control quality.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bangladesh will get $45 million in interest-free loans to help its textile and fertilizer industries, the World Ban k announced today. The loans, to run for 50 years, will be given by t he International Development Association, an affiliate of the bank. A loan of $30 million will go to rehabilitate 15 plants and install c enters to control quality.

docs.abstract: Shah Azizur Rahman has been retained as Prime Minister in President Abdus Sattar's new Cabinet, which was installed today. On Thursday, Mr. Sattar dismissed his 42-member Council of Ministers, charging that many were corrupt, and set up an 18-member group to run the Government.
docs.lead_paragraph: Shah Azizur Rahman has been retained as Prime Minister in President Abdus Sattar's new Cabinet, which was installed today. On Thursday, Mr. Sattar dismissed his 42-member Council of Ministers, charging that many were corrupt, and set up an 18-member group to run the Government.

docs.abstract: President A.F.M. Ahsanuddin Choudhury called on the nation today to cooperate with the martial law authorities in stamping out corruption.   He said in a broadcast that rampant corruption had brought the nation to the edge of ruin.  Mr. Choudhury is a figurehead president with real power being exercised under martial law by the army chief, Lieut. Gen. H.M.  Ershad, who staged a coup last Wednesday.
docs.lead_paragraph: President A.F.M. Ahsanuddin Choudhury called on the nation today to cooperate with the martial law authorities in stamping out corruption.

headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Bangladesh Acts To Stop Corruption

docs.abstract: An overcrowded bus swerved to avoid a speeding truck and plunged 30 feet off a bridge today, killing 28 people and injuring 40, witnesses said. Seventeen passengers were said to have died instantly in the accident 19 miles east of Dacca.
docs.lead_paragraph: An overcrowded bus swerved to avoid a speeding truck and plunged 30 feet off a bridge today, killing 28 people and injuring 40, witnesses said. Seventeen passengers were said to have died instantly in the accident 19 miles east of Dacca.

docs.abstract: Two attaches of the Soviet Embassy here were arrested last week while attempting to burn 588 rolls of movie film, according to sources close to Bangladesh security agents.    The attaches, whose last names are said to be Lomovsky and Kirichuk, were said to have been stopped March 31 by a civilian official about 20 miles northwest of here on the road to Tangail.
docs.lead_paragraph: Two attaches of the Soviet Embassy here were arrested last week while attempting to burn 588 rolls of movie film, according to sources close to Bangladesh security agents.

headline.main: Two Soviet Diplomats Detained in Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Two Soviet Diplomats Detained in Bangladesh

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.abstract: Despite all efforts to show that the military takeover on March 24 spells a better future for Bangladesh, there is a growing feeling here that the martial-law administration of Lieut. Gen. H.M. Ershad has had a less auspicious first week in power than many predicted.   In particular, according to foreign and Bangladeshi sources, the usual saving graces of military rule - administrative stability, elimination of corruption, forceful economic programs - do not look as if they will automatically follow now that the military has overthrown a constitutionally democratic Government that was by most accounts both corrupt and impotent.   Virtually all analysts agree that the coup had been expected for months and seemed somehow inevitable. In fact, several sources say, the coup's military planners were so careful and, for the first time in this nation's coup-ridden history, so open about their intentions that before finally seizing power they not only pushed publicly for a bigger role in Government but actually made inquiries into the likely reactions to its takeover by all the influential sectors of Bangladeshi society.
docs.lead_paragraph: Despite all efforts to show that the military takeover on March 24 spells a better future for Bangladesh, there is a growing feeling here that the martial-law administration of Lieut. Gen. H.M. Ershad has had a less auspicious first week in power than many predicted.

headline.main: BANGLADESH RULER OFF TO SLOW START
headline.print_headline: BANGLADESH RULER OFF TO SLOW START

byline.original: By Colin Campbell, Special To the New York Times

docs.abstract: The nation's martial-law adminstration announced tonight that several former high Government officials and more than 200 other people had been been arrested on charges of corruption, misuse of power and antistate activities.   The administration also announced the appointment of a retired judge, A.S.M. Ahsan, as President of Bangladesh, but he is expected to be only a ceremonial figure. The martial-law ruler, Lieut. Gen.  Hussain Mohammed Ershad, said after seizing power Wednesday that he would appoint a President who would be subject to his advice.   The announcements came at the close of Bangladesh's National Day, which celebrates the start of the 1971 civil war that led to independence from Pakistan for this impoverished country of 90 million people.
docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's martial-law adminstration announced tonight that several former high Government officials and more than 200 other people had been been arrested on charges of corruption, misuse of power and antistate activities.

byline.original: By Colin Campbell, Special To the New York Times

docs.abstract: The army general who Wednesday imposed martial law in Bangladesh said tonight that he hoped democracy could be restored within two years and that political activity might be permitted again in six months.   This country's new chief martial law administrator, Lieut. Gen.  H.M. Ershad, said also that the United States had changed its stand since Wednesday, when the State Department said it regretted the coup. ''They changed their attitude later on,'' General Ershad said without elaborating.
docs.lead_paragraph: The army general who Wednesday imposed martial law in Bangladesh said tonight that he hoped democracy could be restored within two years and that political activity might be permitted again in six months.

headline.main: BANGLADESHI SPEAK OF DEMOCRACY IN 2 YEARS
headline.print_headline: BANGLADESHI SPEAK OF DEMOCRACY IN 2 YEARS

byline.original: By Colin Campbell, Special To the New York Times

docs.abstract: In its 11 years as a nation, Bangladesh has had two political strongmen and many who wanted to be. The latest contender, Lieut.  Gen. H. M. Ershad, the army chief of staff, seized power last week, deposing an elected civilian President, Abdus Sattar.   Sounding like coup leaders usually sound, he claimed to have no personal political ambitions, said he had acted to root out corruption and stem economic decline and promised elections ''as soon as possible.'' In the meantime, his regime declared martial law and arrested several hundred people. Yesterday, he appointed Ahsanuddin Chowdhury, a retired judge, as a figurehead President.
docs.lead_paragraph: In its 11 years as a nation, Bangladesh has had two political strongmen and many who wanted to be. The latest contender, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the army chief of staff, seized power last week, deposing an elected civilian President, Abdus Sattar.

headline.main: The World in Summary; General Steps In In Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: The World in Summary; General Steps In In Bangladesh

byline.original: By Milt Freudenheim and Barbara Slavin

docs.abstract: A consumer group complained to Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that American officials were pressing Bangladesh to delay or reverse its decision to ban more than 1,700 drugs. Many of the drugs, made by American companies, have been removed from the American market.
docs.lead_paragraph: A consumer group complained to Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that American officials were pressing Bangladesh to delay or reverse its decision to ban more than 1,700 drugs. Many of the drugs, made by American companies, have been removed from the American market.

headline.main: Health Group Contends U.S. Presses Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Health Group Contends U.S. Presses Bangladesh
